method_notes: from caterpillar frass in littertraps, and assuming 13% efficiency; this = 4.4% of leaf prod.

variables.name: Biomass_ag
method_notes: measure the diameter of all trees that are¾100¾mm in diameter in a given area (mean 2.1¾ha) at least twice (mean interval 9.4¾years), and apply allometric equations to convert tree-diameter measurements to carbon content

variables.name: ANPP
method_notes: ANPP was calculated by adding tree biomass increment and litterfall during the period of measurement. Aboveground tree biomass was estimated allometrically using tree inventory data and biomass-diameter relation

variables.name: Biomass_ag
method_notes: Aboveground tree biomass was estimated allometrically using tree inventory data and biomass-diameter relation

variables.name: ANPP
method_notes: ANPP was calculated by adding tree biomass increment and litterfall during the period of measurement. Pine, mahogany, and roble (Tabebuia heterophylla (DC.) Britton) trees were harvested to supplement available biomass information on these species. Least squares regression analysis was used to develop bio- mass-diameter relation

variables.name: Biomass_ag
method_notes: Pine, mahogany, and roble (Tabebuia heterophylla (DC.) Britton) trees were harvested to supplement available biomass information on these species. Least squares regression analysis was used to develop biomass-diameter relation

variables.name: Organic_layer
method_notes: multiplying the concentration of organic matter at the center of each soil horizon in the 1 x 1 x 1 m pit by the thickness of the horizon and its bulk density

method_citation: Lugo et al 1992; Sierra et al 2012; Sierra et al 2007

variables.name: ANPP_folivory
method_notes: See Filip et al. 1995. Loss of leaf mass to herbivores was determined from repeated measurements of damage on individually labeled leaves; percent leaf area also measured using discrete measurements over a 3-year period (1983-1985); For the long-term measurements, percent leaf area eaten measured by leaf tracing.

variables.name: ANPP_stem_C
method_notes: Where the individual tree data (including taxonomy) are available, we use allometric equation (Baker et al. 2004) to directly estimate the above-ground biomass at every census.

variables.name: GPP
method_notes: GPP = NPPtotal + Ra = plant carbon expenditure PCE, Metcalfe et al. 2010

variables.name: Rsoil_annual
method_notes: closed dynamic chamber method with an infra-red gas analyser and soil respiration chamber

variables.name: ANPP_branch
method_notes: Harvest (branches > 2 cm diameter), larger branches measured diameter at 3 points, assigned wood density value

variables.name: ANPP_foliage
method_notes: Litter traps, separated into components, oven dried and weighed

variables.name: R_auto_annual
method_notes: Ra = Rleaf + Rstem + Rrhizosphere + Rcoarse root

variables.name: R_foliage_annual

variables.name: R_wood_annual

variables.name: LAI
method_notes: Yearly LAI was calculated by multiplying the average leaf area/mass value for each life form by the estimated leaf biomass in each life form and then summing over life forms.

variables.name: ANPP
method_notes: ANPP was estimated by summing annual litterfall accumulation (897 g/m2/year) plus biomass change due to delayed mortality (142 g/m2/year) plus estimated herbivory (25 g/m2/year)

variables.name: ANPP_folivory
method_notes: Followed herbivory of tagged leaves over 3 mo., to 12 m ht. maximum, got 1% herbivory in 90 days, extrapolated to 4% over a year;converted to /ha with LAI values based on plumb bob data and standing leaf biomass from mass/area relation.
